fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a repository
2. Within the repository, add a file with a path and file name too long for Windows' Explorer to handle (for example using git bash, or using drive-to-folder mapping
3. Open the repository in SourceTree
Expected: it works
Actual: SourceTree crashes with a System.IO.PathTooLongException
4. Commit the file from command line
5. Add any other change to the repository
6. Open the repository in SourceTree again (SourceTree will show the latest-changed repository (ours) and highlight the "Uncommitted changes" item on the commit list)
7. On the commit list, click on the last commit (the one with the long-named file)
Expected: it works
Actual: SourceTree crashes with a System.IO.PathTooLongException

This is related to Windows' ancient limitations regarding path length, however there are workarounds for it (both Git Bash and TortoiseGit work fine with long paths) worthy of the 21st century we live in.
fields.summary: Path Too Long Exception
tutorial

fields.description: I follow the benevolent dictator model for distributed workflows and the software likes to revert my config settings for remote and pushremote. I have to pull from the blessed repo and push to the origin repo (then do a pull request). I am referring to git. I am not sure if hg supports pushremote.
fields.summary: Better support for PushRemotes

fields.description:
If there are multiple files in the Pending list, SourceTree does not go back to "Log / History" tab after committing part of the pending files only.

Even though the option "After committing, stay in commit dialog if there are still pending changes" is selected, SourceTree still does not go back to "Log / History" tab after committing the remaining pending files (can only reproduce by committing more than once in "File Status" tab)

h4.Steps to reproduce
# Edit two files
# Click on Commit toolbar from "Log / History" tab
# Commit one of the file only
# Still remain in "File Status" tab <-- First problem: the option "After committing, stay in commit dialog if there are still pending changes" is not selected so it should go back to "Log / History" tab
# Commit the second file (no more pending files)
# Still remain in "File Status" tab <-- Second problem: should go back to "Log / History" tab
# Edit two files
# Click on Commit toolbar from "Log / History" tab
# Commit the two files (no more pending files)
# SourceTree auto go back to "Log / History" tab
fields.summary: After committing, SourceTree does not go back to "Log / History" tab if there are pending changes

fields.description:
When you work with a great number of repositories it's always difficult to find the ones that you're interested in a the moment in that big flat list !

The best way to address that problem is, from experience, the ability to group items (i.e. switch to a tree structure) and close those groups...

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Open mercurial repository which has file with Windows line breaks ('\r\n'). For example repository https://bitbucket.org/pypy/pypy has such file {{rpython\translator\c\src\stacklet\switch_x64_msvc.asm}}
2. Make some change in file with Windows line breaks
3. Open Source Tree and press "Discard Hunk"
!changed_file_1.png|thumbnail!

*Actual result:* Hunk is discarded but all line breaks are replaced with Unix breaks ('\n')
!changed_file_2.png|thumbnail!
*Expected result:* file {{switch_x64_msvc.asm}} is restored to it's original state.
fields.summary: Windows Linebreaks are replaced with Unix breaks on "Discard Hunk" click
Crash

fields.description:
I created a new local Mercurial repository in an existing folder. I unchecked the checkmark to add a bookmark. The repo opens in SourceTree, but its tab is empty. It only shows the cross used to close the repo tab.

I can refresh the repo view if I want (though it doesn't seem to auto-refresh like it usually does; I have to explicitly press Ctrl+R). After performing a commit, the view isn't refreshed, and when I do refresh, SourceTree crashes.
fields.summary: Crash on refresh of Mercurial repo with empty title

fields.description:
SourceTree unexpectedly crashes when I stage a couple of files and then click on the Commit button on the toolbar

There is a number of repository bookmarks having been added and some of these repositories seem to be no longer available if I read the log file correctly (although *not* the one I am trying to commit to)

The attached error log contains all the technical details, although I had to obfuscate some file paths and URLs as they originally contained sensitive business information I am not authorized to reveal to a 3rd party.

I should also add this is a second or third time SourceTree crashes under similar circumstances since updating to the latest version.
fields.summary: SourceTree crashes upon initiating a commit to a Git repository

fields.description:
I merged a branch into my current branch, and had a number of merge conflicts.  I want to resolve a heap of them by selecting them and right click and select Resolve Conflicts/Resolve Using 'Mine' option.
I get the normal confirmation prompt and when I press OK I get an error message saying: 
"Could not update one or more files, please check that no other application is locking your files."
Restarted my PC and opened on Source Tree and tried again, and still get the same error.  These are just html files, that are not being used by anything.

How can I resolved this and get on with my merge so I can use my working environment again?

Regards,

Scott
fields.summary: Can't Resolve Using Mine

fields.description:
Occasionally when attempting to stage uncommitted changes on a repo, both the "Unstaged files" and "Staged files" panes will be empty although uncommitted changes do in fact exist. Closing the repo tab and opening it again still shows empty panes. When clicking the checkbox beside "Staged files", SourceTree crashes and closes. The log file reports the following exception:

'diff-tree in GetCommitFileChanges' failed with code 128: fatal: ambiguous argument '0': unknown revision or path not in the working tree.
Use '--' to separate paths from revisions, like this:
'git <command> [<revision>...] -- [<file>...]'
fields.summary: Fatal exception when attempting to stage changes

fields.description:
It seems that when deleting a stash in GUI, it is being deleted based on it's position in a list. So if have 3 stashes (let's call them A, B, C), this will happen:
1. I select the first stash (A), right-click delte stash.
2. Operation, takes a while to process, in the meanwhile I right-click and delete the second stash (B).
3. What actually happens is that stashes A and C get delete, while B stays.

Additionally a similar problem happens if I delete B and then C, I will get error message about invalid position.
fields.summary: Delete stash is deleting wrong stash

fields.description:
Sometimes it is impossible to move the splitter between the staging pane and the diff pane on the File Status view.

It moves a few pixels when you start to drag and then jumps back to its original position and will not budge.

Reisizing the split slightly between the File Status tab on the left and the staging pane seems to then allow the splitter to be moved.
fields.summary: Sometimes it is impossible to move the splitter on the File Status tab
SourceTree crashing when collapsing stashes

fields.description:
One of the primary uses of stash is a quick temporary holding area for some changes when you discover there is something you need to do first. Such as merge a change, or fix a config file.

In git they've made this work flow quite quick, {{git stash}}, make your changes {{git pop}}.

In SourceTree though this is made more awkward by having to right click the stash, select apply, check delete after applying, and then click OK.

I think there should be a Stash Pop button in tool bar that simply runs the standard {{git pop}} command.
fields.summary: Stash Pop button in tool bar

fields.description:
I had one file pending, which I wanted to stop tracking, so I right clicked and chose to Stop Tracking, accepting the changes. This file then changes its status to a delete (no entry sign).

Then to commit that change I right clicked on it again, this time choosing "Stop Tracking", which fails and I get an "Oops!" dialogue, and SourceTree closes.

The commit does succeed if I check the checkbox, and use the commit button on the File Status tab.
fields.summary: SoureTree Crashes when Committing a File Using the Context Menu

fields.description:
If the password of the Active Directory was changed by the user SourceTree use the cached Credentials without any Information that the user can not be authenticated. By the security guidelines in our company the user account is blocked after three wrong login attempts.

It would be great if SourceTree could display a popup message after the first failed login attempt. So that the user could change the cached password.
fields.summary: SourceTree blocks Microsoft Active Directory Account

fields.description:
Its impossible to switch the default remote in the Repository Settings as each time you check the default checkbox it renames the remote to origin which clashes with the existing origin.

see the screenshots

see also: https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/sourcetreewin/src/71911287818e7768714cd19faa2ba8f66574c342/ViewModel/RemoteDetailsDialogViewModel.cs?at=master#cl-82

*Work Around*

# Select the 'origin' remote
# unset that as default.
# rename from 'origin' to something else
# Select the other remote
# set as default
## this will rename it to origin, but it will no longer clash.
fields.summary: Unable to set a new default remote for a repo as it gets renamed to origin

fields.description:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Save the attached 'test.jsx' file
2. Add the file to a git repo
3. Change the file
4. Select the file in 'Uncommitted Changes'
4. Observe the build-in diff display

Results:
The previous file and the new file are stacked on top of each other instead of actually diffed. The original is first, so long files look like no changes have happened. The diff incorrectly says there's a new line at the beginning AND a removed line at the beginning.

(See attached screenshot.)

Expected Results:
The diff works as usual.

NOTE: This error occurs on both Mac and PC versions of SourceTree. Also, other .jsx files work fine, so I'm not sure why the attached file is having issues. This might be a BOM problem. Also, checking in the file includes the appropriate changes, so this is a diff preview problem only.
fields.summary: Bad Diff Preview on .jsx File (attached)

fields.description: Would you please add a theme with dark colors? Working with the text based interface with a white background is not easy. A theme with dark colors, would make the interface much easier on the eyes.
fields.summary: Dark colored theme

fields.description:
Opened a repository located on a SMB share like \\theHost\dir\myrepo.
No remote repository was associated with this SMB/Directory repository.

Changing file(s) and committing changes.

Source Tree indicates that one (or more) changes can be pushed.
Push button is avail and shows "1".

Why does SourceTree support/need push when the commit already "pushed" the change on top of repository ( since it is just a directory ) ?

Hitting the push button and canceling the spawned push-dialog.
"Push" indicator in repo list and on the Push-Button disappeared now.

Remark: This unneccesary push does not happen when repositiory is a directory on current host and no remote repo has been associated yet.
fields.summary: SourceTree wants to "push" changes on SMB located repository

fields.description: As can be seen from the screenshots I have set up SourceTree to use "origin" as my default remote, but have another remote called "artesa" as well. When I hit "Commit" and to go "File status" tab SourceTree uses the wrong remote for automatic push. The last attachment shows this. When trying to commit using "automatic push" I get an error that I'm not up to date on my branch. This is for the Artesa repository! When hit "push" after the commit was done, everything works fine (pushing to "origin", NOT "artesa").
fields.summary: Wrong remote selected for auto-pushing when committing

fields.description:
I updated this morning to the suggested version (1.6.5)
The bug: I was reviewing my last changes through SourceTree, then I went back to my editor (Eclipse) to change another small thing. Swapped back to SourceTree which updated itself with the change I made. At this point I right clicked on the file entry (in the unstaged area) that I wanted to commit and hit 'commit'.
After this click the client crashed.
I could reproduce easily this crash just by reopening the client and directly right click on the file to commit. :(

fields.description: When you have multiple remotes defined (one is set as the default), even if your git configuration text file specifies a given remote for a given branch, the checkbox to "Push changes" in the commit message box always points to the first alphabetical removed, regardless of the default of config choice. This leads to accidental commits in the wrong remote.
fields.summary: Commit message "Push changes" checkbox uses wrong remote

Also if you have selected all unstaged files (intentionally or by mistake) only way to unselect all is to change the tab i.e. if you are in File Status, you change it to Log/History or Search and then come back to File Status and then files are unselected.

fields.description:
Any attempt to clone or checkout a branch using Stash 'checkout with Sourcetree' or 'Clone with Sourcetree' results in an error message on the Sourcetree URL Actions window.
Same if I try to start the clone via Sourcetree menu options.

The error message says "This is not a valid source path/URL", with a details button next to it.  When I click details, I get a truncated message "fatal: Cannot change to 'C:/Users/charlie.stott.ECC/..': Permission denied"

As you see, this message contains a truncated parameter and I cannot expand the window or message box to see the full message.

I have removed all mentions of the partial path from my settings.

I have tried system and embedded versions of git and mercurial, enabled them, and relocated the global ignore lists.

When I try to clone from sourcetree menus, I get the same error and details button, and same details shown when i click the button.  When I try to change the URL (trying ssh://.. http://.. https://..), the message flashes to ... then gives the same error.

Please tell me what sourcetree is looking for down this path and how I can fix this problem.

Sourcetree is being used by my entire team, but I cannot get past this error, neither can my sysadmin find any problem.

I have searched for a solution and found many people with similar issues, but no resolution, other than reinstall (which I have tried) and pointers to ssh and git settings.

I can use git on the command line with or without ssh.  This implies that stash, git and ssh are all working just fine.

I am sure it is a simple matter, but without knowing the full path that is problematic, I cannot find any way to fix myself.
fields.summary: cannot use sourcetree due to illegible error message

fields.description:
I upgraded sourcetree today (1.6.5.0) and I found a really bothersome bug. I can commit staged files by clicking on the commit button, but when I try to commit with the keyboard shortcut (alt + shift + C) the app crashes and exits with a generic message.

Here's what is left in my log after the crash:

2014-10-01T11:26:41: Fatal error: 
System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.

2014-10-01T11:26:41: Stack trace: 
   at SourceTree.ViewModel.RepoTabViewModel.CommitSelected()
   at SourceTree.ViewModel.Utils.CommandSink.ExecuteCommand(ICommand command, Object parameter, Boolean& handled)
   at SourceTree.ViewModel.Utils.CommandSinkBinding.<set_CommandSink>b__1(Object s, ExecutedRoutedEventArgs e)
   at System.Windows.Input.CommandBinding.OnExecuted(Object sender, ExecutedRoutedEventArgs e)
   at System.Windows.Input.CommandManager.ExecuteCommandBinding(Object sender, ExecutedRoutedEventArgs e, CommandBinding commandBinding)
   at System.Windows.Input.CommandManager.FindCommandBinding(CommandBindingCollection commandBindings, Object sender, RoutedEventArgs e, ICommand command, Boolean execute)
   at System.Windows.Input.CommandManager.FindCommandBinding(Object sender, RoutedEventArgs e, ICommand command, Boolean execute)

fields.summary: Commit Shortcut Crashes SourceTree

fields.description: Sometimes the application locates the indicated (see attached image) vertical windows split at the 50% position, and does not allow the divider to be moved/adjusted left or right.  After fiddling with the app's window size (minimize/maximize), sometimes the window split can then be adjusted.   (the attached image was taken after a successful adjustment)
fields.summary: Vertical window split sometimes does not allow adjustment

fields.description:
Did update, was able to pull successfully. Every time I try to commit, ST crashes and closes the program.

fields.summary: crash when trying to commit

fields.description: I have 135 remote branches in my repository. I would only like to see a subset of those in the Log/History view.
fields.summary: Allow selection of branches to show

fields.description:
Many people have ultra-wide (or multiple) monitors with enough screen real estate to have multiple windows side by side. It would be nice to be able to have the tree view and staging/diff areas side by side to give them both more room. I mocked up a basic idea of what I'd like to see.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Side by side layout for wide monitors

fields.description:
At present there isn't a good way to find the details of a particular commit from the log window.
The functionality provided by the 'View In Full Log' context menu doesn't work in my use case.

I work in an environment with lots of developers, where there are 100+ commits on our master branch every day, so if I click on the View In Full Log option for anything more than a couple of days old it fails to find what it is looking for and nothing happens.

I've raised this as a bug on the existing functionality as it just doesn't work properly, but in an ideal work what I would like is something similar to what you have in the Search view, where you can see the commit details for each commit in the log window.
Even if the bug is fixed to show older items in the full log properly then if I am trying to view the commit details for a change two years ago then it will have to load tens of thousands of items in the log view, which doesn't seem like a workable solution.

At present there is no good way to do what I want, which causes significant pain when trying to look at historical changes.
fields.summary: 'View In Full Log' menu item from log window doesn't work in many cases.

fields.description: When staging a file (by checking the checkbox next to it), the first file in the list of changes files will be selected. It would make more sense to select the file below the one that was staged.
fields.summary: Staging a file should move the selection to the one below it

fields.description: Make links to Jira clickable when a Jira issue number has been entered as plaintext in a commit message. This would be a nice and subtle improvement to durther integrating Atlassian products. This would need an option in the preferences where the user's running instance of Jira can be found.
fields.summary: Make Jira links clickable

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
* Click the "Discard" button in the UI.
* SourceTree shows a window with two files changed.
* Click one one file and select "discard"

Expected results:
* Changes to the selected file are discarded.

Actual results:
* Changes to the other file are discarded.

Not sure if this is because I sorted the discard file window in a way that is unexpected, but that would definitely make sense.
fields.summary: "DISCARD" feature discards changes to the wrong file

fields.description: SourceTree should persist my preference whether to "Remember Password" or not during authentication of commiting/pushing source code. After code modification on my local repository when pushing the changes the authentication prompt always has the "Remember Password" checkbox checked. Each time I have to uncheck the box before I continue. SourceTree should persist this preference.
fields.summary: SourceTree should persist the preference to "Remember Password" during commit/push authentication.

fields.description: I'd absolutely love to be able to wire up a toolbar button to a custom repository action, to do things like open up the project in my editor or run my deployment utility with a single click.
fields.summary: Toolbar buttons from custom actions

fields.description:
When there are changed files, the Log/History tab shows "Uncommitted changes" at the top of the commit list. When there are no changed files, "Uncommitted changes" disappears. Appearing and disappearing while I'm working is distracting and sometimes confusing.

It would be better if "Uncommitted changes" were always visible and just showed no files when there are no changes. TortoiseHg works like this and it's wonderful.

This is similar to SRCTREEWIN-1971.
fields.summary: Make "Uncommitted changes" always visible on Log/History tab

fields.description:
When I right-click on a changed file, the contextual menu has an entry labelled "Discard". That term is ambiguous and could mean "delete the file". It's also not clear how it is different from "Remove" in that same menu.

I suggest changing "Discard" to "Discard Changes" for clarity.
fields.summary: Change "Discard" to "Discard Changes" for clarity

fields.description: When trying to delete a large amount of branches, the dialog box to confirm branch deletion does not scroll, so you cannot scroll down to click the "OK" button.
fields.summary: Dialog Box For Delete Branches Does Not Scroll

fields.description:
I'm working with a git repo, and everytime I minimize SourceTree and then later bringing it to the foreground, it hangs for 20+ seconds!
You have to wait all the time and that's really annoying!

It seems to me like the program refreshes something everytime I bring the window to the foreground.
fields.summary: Hanging for long time when window comes to foreground

fields.description:
When viewing the uncommitted changes, select all the files (CTRL+A is one quick way).

Now try to unselect a file. Or unselect all files.

Normally clicking on one of the files would be the mechanism to select just one - not a click-hold-drag which would start the drag/drop process, just a single click.

None of the SHIFT/CTRL/ALT + click options do anything when the files are selected.

The only option is to stage all the files and then unstage the one that wasn't wanted to start with.
fields.summary: Cannot unselect changed files when all files selected

fields.description:
After that "update" to 1.6 and all the problems and inefficiencies it introduced, I was envious at all my colleagues that were still running 1.5.

Luckily, it's possible to download 1.5 from your website although there's no explicit link. Still, could you please add a link to "older versions" to your download website? That would make it easier for other folks that prefer the older UI, too.
fields.summary: Make Older Versions Available

fields.description:
I created a commit followed by a commit with the same message preceded with fixup!

When I attempt to perform an interactive rebase a message box appears.
fields.summary: Interactive rebase with a commit containing fixup! produces a Test message box.

fields.description:
In the installation directory, the tools/openssh_wrapper.sh is having Windows eol and causing warnings when I perform git operations inside Source Tree.

Changing the eol using `dos2unix` eliminated the warnings.

BTW, I'm using cygwin git 2.1.1
fields.summary: Wrong eol in tools/openssh_wrapper.sh
crash

fields.description:
If you changed password to access remote repository - SourceTree does not 'pick it up'. When you do pull it reports 'up do date' result, but I know for sure that there are changes in the remote. If you open a console and do a *git pull* there - then changes are downloaded and the next time you try to use SourceTree it prompts for new credentials.

How to reproduce:
# Setup a repository and work with it
# Change password (in my case - domain password)
# Ask someone to make a change in origin
# Do a pull in SourceTree. *Actual Result* - 'Already up-to-date.'. *Expected result* - dialog to enter new password.

Workaround:
# Open terminal
# Do a *git pull*
# Do a pull operation in SourceTree
fields.summary: Failed authentication after changing git account password is not reported

fields.description: I have pulled changes from origin and collapsed *Tags* node in the tree.
fields.summary: SourceTree crush when collapsing Tags (not reproducable)

fields.description: After committing, the File Status View switches to Log View without my asking it to.
fields.summary: Switch to Log View after Commit

fields.description: We work with a lot of repositories, and it is very easy to open dozens of tabs. Right now I have to close them one by one in order to keep my workspace a bit tidy. Perhaps we could have a feature where we right-click on a tab and choose "Close All Tabs" and/or "Close All Tabs But This", like we have in Visual Studio and web browsers?
fields.summary: Close All Tabs / Close All Tabs But This

fields.description: On adding one of our software repos (located on a remote filer, but I don't think that makes a difference) SourceTree crashes. From the log it looks like it may not like a particular format.
fields.summary: Crash on adding a particular git repo

fields.description: SourceTree crashed, it was open and when I tabbed to it to pull files it crashed.  Not sure of any exact reason why.  I've attached the log file which contains a stack trace.
fields.summary: Application Crashed

fields.description:
Currently, when moving repos around the bookmarks, and in folders in particular, when you drag over a folder, it opens the folder immediately. That means by the time you get through all of the bookmarks, each folder is opened, and you are looking at a mess of 100+ repos, that you have to scroll around.

Some possible alternatives:
1. Put a delay (2 seconds?) on the hover before opening
2. Close the folder after exiting the hover over the folder.
3. Close the folder dropping the hovered item.
4. Pop up a tool tip with the folder contents (instead of opening it)

Also, can you offer some keyboard/menu shortcuts to close/open all folders?

In the end, I think we should have a more robust bookmark management tool. One that has two modes: search/discover and management/add/remove

We definitely need search (of bookmarked repositories). At least by repo/directory name. I mentioned before it would be nice to add search to the project.

We should also have a way to add like music add's. I.e. search/monitor all these folders... Add bookmarks automatically.


Thanks! LOVE your product!
fields.summary: Bookmark management

fields.description: This happens when a git repository is deleted while SourceTree is open
fields.summary: Error encountered Error encountered Error encountered

fields.description: When clicking on Finish Hotfix action, the hotfix branch is merged only in prod and not in develop branch.
fields.summary: Hg Flow finish hotfix not merging into develop

fields.description:
I've added a key (not PUTTY) and on start the ssh agent starts, but closes quickly so I can't enter the pw.

I've to add the key everytime I need the connection
first I added it every time, but once I recognized, that I've the same key more then 4 times in my "key path"

some versions earlier it worked fine
fields.summary: SSH-Agent doesn't ask password and so I've to re-add it (and afterwards remove them except one)

fields.description:
Please update this tracker. 1.6.2 and 1.6.4 are not *unreleased* versions.

That being said, if you have multiple copies of the same repository open (think submodules used in different projects), then all tabs will have the same name and it is impossible to determine which tab corresponds to which repository.

A tooltip on the tab label, which would show the full path, would be sufficient IMHO.
fields.summary: Make it clear what repository a tab belongs to
